The cingulate gyrus or cortex is a part of the brain that lies in the medial aspect of each cerebral hemisphere, just above the corpus callosum. It is an essential component of the limbic system and is involved in various cognitive, emotional, motor and physiological functions.

Some important roles played by cingulate gyrus are:

1. Emotional processing: The anterior part of the cingulate gyrus has connections with other limbic structures such as amygdala and nucleus accumbens. This enables it to participate in emotional regulation by controlling fear responses, expressing emotion through facial expressions, vocalizations and gestures.

2. Attention and motivation: Studies have shown that the anterior cingulate cortex plays a crucial role in attention processes by detecting conflicting situations (e.g., choosing between two simultaneously presented options) and allocating necessary resources for their resolution.

3. Pain perception: The mid-cingulate cortex has been associated with pain perception both in terms of intensity evaluation as well as subjective suffering related to this experience

4. Motor control: The posterior portion of the cingulate gyrus helps coordinate voluntary movement using feedback from various sensory systems; it also contributes to spatial orientation during body movements.
